Award.AwardTitle: KSU Student Chapter of the IEEE EMBS as a Focal Point for Senior Design Projects to Aid Children with Disabilities

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Warren, Steven, Evans, Shelby and Natarajan, Balasubramaniam
Proposal Number: 10067740

Seniors in secondary engineering programs offer a diverse skill set that can address a myriad of quality-of-life issues faced by disabled children. Multidisciplinary design projects at this level can assist with activities of daily living, health monitoring, and education within the confines of the environments where disabled children seek to thrive: classrooms, homes, and communities. The overall goal of this proposed collaboration is to establish a sustainable relationship between the Kansas State University (KSU) College of Engineering (COE) and Heartspring in Wichita, KS, where design talents of KSU students are directed toward solutions to challenges faced by severely disabled children at Heartspring (most of whom have an Autism Spectrum Disorder), the paraeducators that work with them one-on-one, and the clinical and administrative staff that guide those programs.
Seven objectives support this goal:
- Define senior design projects that enhance student and para quality of life by facilitating activities of daily living, improving student health, and accelerating education.
- Implement these engineering solutions immediately within the classroom, home, and community environments served by Heartspring.
- Emphasize projects that increase caregivers' situational awareness for disabled children by quantifying dynamics within their local environment, state of health, and educational progress.
- Seek solutions that help to reduce the burden of care imposed upon paraeducators, starting with automated collection and transmission of student date.
- Align senior projects with existing structured courses and independent, special topics courses at KSU to efficiently deliver these experiences and maintain buy-in from students and instructors.
- Funnel projects through the KSU Student Chapter of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society (EMBS) to bring together students from all COE departments and serve as a rallying hub for impactful multidisciplinary projects.
- Disseminate the designs produced by these efforts and the associated clinical effectiveness results so as to maximize the impact of these investments on the disabled community.
From an Intellectual Merit viewpoint, this approach is timely and apt. The health and safety of disabled children can be improved by efficiency and productivity increases offered by custom and off-the-shelf mobile, wireless technologies usually applied in other business sectors. Such pervasive technology tools can be embedded in learning and living environments to assist with situational awareness and reduce the burden of care. Improved outcomes in shorter periods of time are inevitable.
Regarding Broader Impact, this effort will (a) strengthen the KSU EMBS student chapter, (b) generate KSU COE excitement regarding biomedical projects, (c) increase the quality and impact of senior design experiences since design will be immediately tested in the intended Heartspring application environment, (d) serve as a recruiting tool to foster the participation of female students in KSU COE programs, and (e) increase research participation of disabled children, an underrepresented group in multiple societal and research contexts. This effort will also inevitably lead to larger Heartspring/KSU efforts that will increase technology resources for use with other populations that have similar functional independence needs. The hope of this team is to use technology as an "outcomes force multiplier" to help the disability services community (1) reduce the disproportionate cost of special education, (2) increase the resource base available to meet the growing need, and (3) provide solutions of scale that can be implemented and deployed quickly.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A child with severe disabilities needs unique assistance with communication, activities of daily living, mobility, learning, social engagement, etc. that may be hard to address with commercial products and traditional assistive technology. Likewise, a clinician or paraeducator (para) that works with a child may find it difficult to obtain resources that assist with their care or allow a caregiver to quantify the child's progress. The overall goal of this 6-year effort, funded by the National Science Foundation (NSF) GARDE program, was to identify such unique needs, on behalf of these children or their caregivers, and then address those needs with design efforts pursued by teams of students enrolled in the Kansas State University (KSU) College of Engineering. Heartspring, Wichita, KS provided the clinical motivation for each project, informed by the needs of the children that stay in Heartspring apartments year-round, where nearly all of these children have an Autism Spectrum Disoder (ASD) and most are non-verbal. NSF funds were made available to purchase equipment and material to support these design endeavors, but funds were not used to pay student wages or supplement instructor salaries.

The design space related to children with ASD is broad and addresses tools to

- maximize child safety in residential, educational, and therapeutic environments,

- establish situational awareness for these children, including quantifying their wellness during the daytime/nighttime,

- track parameters associated with outcomes-based therapies as specified in individualized education plans,

- assist children with activities of daily living,

- increase the effectiveness of educational activities,

- aid in the delivery and effectiveness of physical, social, and cognitive therapies,

- track children and paras within their daily environments with a goal to optimize facility use, care-delivery processes, and the impact of human resources, and

- increase the well-being of parents, paras, clinicians, and administrators that work with these children.

Designs intended to quantify child well-being or to assist them with learning or activities of daily living are often by nature "one of" designs tightly matched to these needs. Such designs must be incorporated into environments in unobtrusive ways to avoid upsetting or distracting these children. This design space and its affiiliated challenges offer a rich environment for engineering students to exercise their design creativity. Such technology-based products also address cross-cutting requirements: a reduced burden of care, increased independence, and a focus on health and safety for this vulnerable population.

While numerous design ideas were discussed during this 6-year effort, a few projects stood out in terms of their potential impact. These projects include

- armguard designs to protect paras from bite injuries,

- wearable units to monitor self-injurious behavior,

- an electroencephalograph cap to track a child's emotional state,

- a wrist-worn device to measure galvanic skin response toward identifying a child's or para's emotional state,

- a musical toothbrush to help teach a child how to brush their teeth while at the same time tracking their brushing activity,

- wearable sensors to acquire physiological information,

- tracking devices to ascertain child location indoors,

- a sensor glove to help a para quickly record behaviors,

- shoe sensors to quantify gait for rehabilitation therapy,

- antennas that can be sewn into a child's clothing,

- surface computer games to quantify learning and to help children learn social behavior, and

- a sensor-based bed that can track a child's heart rate, breathing rate, movement, sleep cycles, bedwetting, etc. throughout the night, where the child would have no knowledge that their normal bed would be monitoring their health as they slept.

The latter received additional NSF GARDE funding because of its promise to track the nighttime health and well-being of multiple populations.

These NSF funds supported design projects in the KSU departments of Electrical & Computer Engineering, Biological & Agricultural Engineering, Mechanical & Nuclear Engineering, and Industrial & Manufacturing Systems Engineering through various courses. While it is difficult to count the exact number of students and faculty engaged with these efforts (e.g., because a student may have worked on multiple projects over multiple years), the investigators estimate that ~200 students and faculty have been involved with this work since the project onset. Additionally, ~225 KSU students enrolled in ECE 571 - Introduction to Biomedical Engineering course were tasked with proposing two-semester design experiences based on the needs of children with severe disabilities.

While few of the design experiences resulted in products used by children or their caregivers, the investigators believe that the long-term benefit of this work is consistent with the project's goal to use technology as an "outcomes force multiplier" to help the disability services community (1) reduce the disproportionate cost of special education, (2) increase the resource base available to meet the growing need for products that assist the disabled, and (3) provide solutions of scale that can be implemented and deployed in a meaningful way.
